data.title: Atom 1.12.9 Spec Suite call stack unreadable due to color/background color combination.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Running Atom 1.12.9 on Ubuntu 16.04 (LTS). Originally detected on Atom 1.12.7. Not tested on earlier versions.

While running specs on a package I am developing, the text in the call stack is unreadable due to the background color for `pre` being set to `#31363f` and the text color being set in `.stack-trace` to `#666`. 

Additionally, the Spec Suite window does not appear to honor Theme changes or settings in `~/.atom/styles.less`.

#### Screenshot

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/619697/21777258/1a679748-d66c-11e6-8343-87fef0ba5725.png)

Using Developer Tools, the computed value `#31363f` for `background-color` for `pre` is purportedly set in `atom.less`. The text `color`  `#666` is being set by `.stack-trace` as an embedded style sheet.

WHAT I HAVE TRIED:

Run in safe mode. No change.

I edited the color of `.stack-trace` in `~/.atom/styles.less` to the following:

```css
pre.stack-trace {
    background-color: white;
}
```

Also tried:

```css
.stack-trace {
    background-color: white;
}
```

```css
pre {
    background-color: white;
}
```

There is no effect to the Spec Suite window.

Tried changing themes. No changes to Spec Suite window. Attempted Theme combinations:

UI Themes:
- Atom Dark
- Atom Light
- One Dark
- One Light

Syntax Themes:
- Atom Dark
- Atom Light
- One Light
- Solarized Light

Since there was no observable difference in the Spec Suite window from any of the above changes, I abandoned this route.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run Specs with an error so as to display call stack
2. Display of call stack is unreadable due to lack of color contrast

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

EITHER:

- Colors should have contrast OR 
- Spec Suite window should honor style overrides in `~/.atom/styles.less`.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/619697/21777258/1a679748-d66c-11e6-8343-87fef0ba5725.png)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

OS       : Ubuntu 16.04

### Additional Information

None

data.title: Don't add pane items in built-in resource openers
data.body: Calling `workspace.open` in an opener doesn't work properly with options like `split: left` because it causes the opened item to be added to the workspace as a side-effect. Since workspace openers are intended to be used during the process of calling `workspace.open`, we need to use `openTextFile`, which just creates an editor but does not attach it to the workspace.

data.title: Install only the 64 bit version of libXss.so.1
data.body:
Fixes #13417.

Considering that the .rpm package we release is for `x86_64` architectures, there should be no need to install i686 dependencies. With this pull request we are installing `libXss.so.1()(64bit)` instead of the more generic `libXss.so.1` to prevent extra dependencies from being installed on users' systems.

This works egregiously on Fedora, but it would be great to confirm it runs flawlessly on all Linux distros that support the .rpm packaging system. @ungb: can you help me with that, please? ðŸ™‡

data.title: Using "Open with Atom" on files from same folder results in multiple windows
data.body:
This bug was reproduced by a moderator at Atom and he asked me to file this bug report.


### Description

In Windows 10 Home 64bit, with Atom closed, choosing multiple files (HTML, CSS) in the same folder in explorer, and "open with Atom" results in a mess of differently sized Atom windows with partly redundant tabs.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Atom should be closed.
2. Select multiple files (HTML, CSS) from the same folder in explorer.
3. Context menu, "Open with Atom"


**Expected behavior:** Atom should open a single window

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens multiple windows

**Reproduces how often:** 100%


### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5

Windows 10 Home 64bit, current version

data.title: Less optional imports fail to parse in UI and syntax themes
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

This issue cannot be reproduced in safe mode, as it concerns external themes. I have met the other prerequisites.

### Description

When a UI or syntax theme which uses a Less file that contains an [optional import](http://lesscss.org/features/#import-options-optional) is selected, the Less file in question fails to parse and the theme fails to activate.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone [atom-community/ui-theme-template](https://github.com/atom-community/ui-theme-template).
2. In `index.less`, change `@import "styles/ui-variables";` to `@import (optional) "styles/ui-variables";`.
3. Run `apm link` in the root of the repository.
4. Navigate to the themes section of the settings screen and select "Ui Theme Template" from the UI themes dropdown list.

It also reproduces with syntax themes.

1. Generate a syntax theme using `package-generator:generate-syntax-theme` from [atom/package-generator](https://github.com/atom/package-generator).
2. In `index.less`, change `@import "./styles/base.less";` to `@import (optional) "./styles/base.less";`.
3. Navigate to the themes section of the settings screen and select the generated theme from the syntax themes dropdown list.

**Expected behavior:** The theme activates successfully.

**Actual behavior:** The theme fails to activate, and a "Error compiling Less stylesheet" notification message is displayed with the message "expected ')' got 'o'".

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]

### Additional Information

Attempting to use an import option that Less does not support (e.g. foobar) yields an error message of the same format e.g. expected ')' got 'f'. [According to the Less changelog](https://github.com/less/less.js/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#230), optional imports were added in 2.3. At current, [less-cache uses 2.7.1](https://github.com/atom/less-cache/blob/v0.24.0/package.json#L31). I have tested Less 2.7.1 separately, and optional imports parsed without error. Less' other import options seem to parse in themes without any issue.

data.title: Data loss when exiting Atom with unsaved files
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When exiting Atom with one or more unsaved files, there is no confirmation to exit without saving, and the content of any unsaved files is completely lost. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Start a new file
3. Add some content to the file
4. Exit Atom (e.g, by clicking the "X" icon in the window, or by using File --> Quit)
5. Re-open Atom
6. File content is gone! 

**Expected behavior:** 

Atom should either automatically save files that have not been saved when closed (e.g, like Sublime Text does by default), or confirm with the user that they would like to exit without saving changes. 

**Actual behavior:** 

There is no confirmation to exit, nor is there any automatic saving. This means the content of any unsaved files is lost! 

**Reproduces how often:**
100% 

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS: Linux Mint 18 "Sarah", Linux 4.7.5-040705-generic #201609240533 SMP Sat Sep 24 09:35:42 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

data.body:

Opening a file that does not belong to a project folder that has been added to the current session results in an incorrect file path being displayed on the title bar, making it look like the open file is actually part of the first project folder in the list.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom on a macOS machine
2. Add some project folders if none exist
3. Using finder, open a file outside of any project folder currently added
4. Note that the file path displayed in the title bar points to the first project folder in the list, not the actual file location.

**Expected behavior:** Opening any file in Atom displays the correct path to the file, always.

**Actual behavior:** Opening a file that is not part of an 'added' project folder displays an incorrect path to the file in the title bar.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.7

Electron: 1.3.13

Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82

Node    : 6.5.0


### Additional Information

See screenshot - the  correct path to ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md is displayed in the status bar (\~/Desktop), but not in the title bar (\~/Projects/node-steam)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/901721/21746316/6b5e94f4-d594-11e6-98c1-1a4f319c84e0.png)

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom preserves some command line flags when it restarts as can be seen in this merged PR #12733. 

But the --disable-gpu flag is not among them and my VM config produces black screen glitches when I don't use it.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Launch atom with --disable-gpu and use ps or system monitor to find the command line with the flag
2. Update extensions and click the restart button or use the developer tools console and call atom.restartApplication()
3. Once restarted check the command line again and the --disable-gpu is no longer there (you can see the glitch in my case because of the gpu bug).

**Expected behavior:** GPU acceleration remains disabled after restart.

**Actual behavior:** GPU acceleration is enabled after restart.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

The GPU issue is this #12461 but seems to affect all electron/chromium related apps and it's probably a hardware vendor/VirtualBox problem.

data.title: opening a file in a new window is unnecessarily difficult
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

This has been tested on macOS and Windows, with macOS being the target platform.

Suppose we want to use two Atom windows on a regular basis. The window opened second seems to be a second-class citizen and does not behave as a user of other editors (e.g. Sublime, TextWrangler, Notepad++, etc) might expect.

For instance, if you drag-and-drop a file from Finder into Atom, it opens in a new tab. This is great, except if we drag to the Secondary window. This will open the file in the Primary window, which is Not Good. This scenario is our main issue, however there are two more issues which exacerbate the problem:

- One is unable to open the Tree View in the Secondary window. Selecting the menu option or using the keyboard shortcut does nothing. So, the Main issue cannot be circumvented in this way.

- Dragging a tab from the Primary window to the Secondary window creates a duplicate of the tab. This would be neat if both buffers were updated simultaneously, but since they are not, it ends up being confusing, and therefore results in the extra step of having to close the first tab.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open the Atom editor
2. Open a New Window (you will now have two distinct windows)
3. Drag a file into the window created second
4. The file will appear in the first window

**Expected behavior:** The file should appear in the window targeted by the user, and nowhere else.

**Actual behavior:** The file appears in the first window created, no matter what. Other issues, as described above, make this more annoying than it might otherwise be.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% - Always

### Versions

macOS 10.12.2 - Atom 1.12.8
Windows 10 v1607 - Atom 1.12.9

### Additional Information

This can be reproduced on a clean install of Atom, with no additional configuration or packages.

data.title: The entire editor breaks when a UI theme's ui-variables.less causes the Less compiler to error
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

The problem cannot be reproduced in safe mode, as safe mode does not load packages and themes. I recognise that the problem is caused by a package external to Atom. I believe that this is a valid issue despite this. I have met the other prerequisites.

### Description

When a UI theme is selected with a `styles/ui-variables.less` file which would cause the Less compiler to error, and Atom is reloaded, the editor fails to load, and the window remains an empty white box.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone [atom-community/ui-theme-template](https://github.com/atom-community/ui-theme-template).
2. Append `#` on a new line to `styles/ui-variables.less`. Alternatively, `@foo: @bar;` can be appended, where `@bar` is undefined. This also reproduces the issue. 
3. Run `apm link --dev` in the root of the repository.
4. Open Atom in developer mode (`atom --dev`), navigate to the themes section of the settings screen, and select "Ui Theme Template" from the UI themes dropdown list.
5. Reload Atom in developer mode (I tried both `ctrl + alt + r`, and simply closing Atom and re-opening it with `atom --dev`).

I have only reproduced the problem in developer mode. I have not attempted to reproduce the problem in Atom's normal mode, as I fear being unable to reverse it.

**Expected behavior:** The editor loads.

**Actual behavior:** The editor does not load, and the window remains an empty white box. The Chromium developer tools automatically open to the console.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.9
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

### Description

The create package bug report action can sometime include too much data (like a looong stacktrace) on the query parameter which results in the Github "New Issue" page failing with 414 error in the browser.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Find an appropriate bug. For me, the current issue is with the `navigation-history` package, but it is not specific to one package, it is probably due to the user (me!) having many packages in "Disabled" mode perhaps.

data.title: Add did-load-user-keymap event
data.body:
### Description of the Change

This change adds an event that fires after the user keymap has successfully loaded. It should be broadly useful in packages but is specifically being added in service of the MRU tab setting as described below.

### Applicable Issues

This is necessary for adding an [MRU tab traversal setting](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11035) in a way that won't alter behavior for users who have already modified their keymaps to turn it off. At package init time the user keymap has not yet loaded so it's not possible to check for them.

data.title: `Config` class needs documentation about keys that aren't in the config schema
data.body:
The [`Config` API class](https://atom.io/docs/api/latest/Config) has a lot of documentation around defining a configuration schema for your package. What it doesn't have good documentation for is that you can `get`, `set`, `observe` and etc values that do not appear in the configuration schema for your package. For example, if "some-package"s config schema is:

```
config:
  someSetting:
    type: 'boolean'
    default: false
```

One can still do the following:

```
let otherSetting  = atom.config.get('some-package.otherSetting')
atom.config.set('some-package.stillAnotherSetting', otherSetting * 5)
```

This needs to be made more clear in the documentation.

data.title: Changed "git-core" package to "git-all" to support "git submodule" coâ€¦
data.body:
### Requirements

In Fedora, RHEL and CentOS git-core package doesn't support "git submodule" command, so the build script break, I changed to "git-all" to enable it.

### Description of the Change

Simple change "git-core" package to "git-all" in Fedora, RHEL and CentOS

### Alternate Designs

Nothing

### Why Should This Be In Core?

To enable others users to build Atom

### Benefits

Correct the build script in Fedora, RHEL and CentOS

### Possible Drawbacks

More dependencies installed

### Applicable Issues

Can't build Atom since the "git-core" package haven't the "submodule" command

data.title: php and javascript mixed breaks the highlighting of the editor
data.body:

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If I have a php- or phtml-file with a script-tag, where I enter some php-code. The editor-highlighting becomes wrong after this php-Statement

### Steps to Reproduce

1. create a php-file
2. write some HTML
3. create a script-tag
4. write a php-tag inside of this script-tag
5. the HTML after this php-tag is all wrong highlighted

**Expected behavior:** The Code after the php-inside-the-script-tag is highlighted normal

![fine](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15897388/21679278/7579efa4-d343-11e6-88a3-e69ce01c905a.png)

**Actual behavior:** The Code after the php-inside-the-script-tag is all black and red

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15897388/21679279/78c96d4c-d343-11e6-969d-f3732e491a15.png)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
